div.p: THE REVOLTEX A TRAGE-COMEDY Acted between the Hind and Panther, AND RELIGIO LAICI, &c.
London, Printed in the Year 1687.

div.head: THE REVOLTER. A Trage-Comedy.
div.p:
THE Hind and the Pantherâ€”Certainly the Author of this Poem, deerves to be reckon'd in the number of the Heathen Gods; For he has out-done all Natales Comes's Deities, and has made new Metamorphoes's to make a econd Ovid more work, far more wonderful then thoe of the Ancient Pagan Divinities. For he has chang'd the Church of Rome into a Hind, the Church of England into a Panther, the Presbyterians into Wolves, the Independents into Bears, the Quakers into Hares, Libertines into Apes, the Anabaptits into Boares, the Socinians into Foxes. And now the Beats begin to talk and parley together again, and the Hind and the Panther enter into a long and erious Debate, as in the Days of Aeop; only with this difference, that Aeop's Beats were all Moralits, but thee Poetical Fictions are all Chritians, and dipute and contend about things of a higher Nature. Truly, one would think the Author
might have bethought himelf of Alluions much more proper for his purpoe than uch Beatial Proopopeia's as thee; now altogether Antiquated, notwithtanding his idle Apology for what he has done, and his mierable Preident of Mother Hubbard, as much out of fahion, as Hellen of Troys Wardrobe, or his Eye-ore of Q. Eliabeth's Fardingale. Nor do we find that ever Chrit, who poke o much in Learned Parables, ever inpir'd the Brutes with Language to colour his Intructions. But the Poet's over-haty, which made it the more Officious Malice, having engag'd him to turn all the Dienters into Beats; and not being able to purue his Allegory, unles he made Beats of the Church of Rome, and the Church of England likewie, has reolv'd to train a Complement with both; and rather than loe the pleaing Conception of his Brain, like a compaionate Numen, to change the one into a Hind; and like an irritated Daemon, to tranform the other into a Panther.

But while he ate thus in his Poetical Throne, or rather acting upon the Stage of Fable and Pagan Muthologie, and transfiguring into Beats almot all Mankind but Turks and Infidels, that were out of his Road, he never conider'd what a Monter he was himelf; a econd Geryon with three Heads: for each of which he had a particular Employment; with the one to fawn upon the mot infamous of Uurpers; with the other, at one time to lick the Beneficent Hands of his Protetant Mother; and by and by to court the Charity of his Catholick Mamma; while with the third, he bark'd and narl'd, not only at his firt deerted Female Parent, but alo at all other differing Sentiments and Opinions, which his Soveraign had o graciouly and generouly indulg'd.

lg.l: BUT 'twas his Wrath, becaue his Native Church
Left his high Expectations in the lurch:
And well he might; for well he knew how oon
His Mue her early Whoredoms had begun;
And thought it brave to be a Cromwel's Jade,
Like Pathic Caear under Nicomede.
She aw the Play-wright Laureate debauh'd
By the Times Vices which himelf reproach'd:
And by his Grand Reform of Stage-pit Fools,
Judg'd his Ability to manage Souls.
The Comedy, to ee him preach, for ought
She knew, might Tragic prove to thoe he taught;
By ill Intructions to their los beguil'd,
Or corning Precepts from a Tongue defil'd,
With Stage-Obcenityâ€”
For who could have refrain'd from portive Mirth,
To hear the Nation's Poet Bayes hold forth?
Or who would ever practie by the Rule
Of one they could not chue but ridicule?
The Scandal was the greater, the more rare;
An ordain'd Play-wright in the Houe of Prayer.
While People only flock to hear him Chime
A rampant Sermon forth in Bully Rhime:
Or ele his gaping Auditors he Feats,
With bold Iaiah's Raptures, and Ezekiel's Beats.
All this the Church foreaw, nor could endure
Polluted Lips hould handle Things mot pure.
At thee Rebuffs th'offended Bayes retires,
Summons together his Poetic Fires,
And all the rage that frantic Spite inpires.
Did I for this, quo he, (for Anger is the Soul
Of Paion, and mut all my Chritian Thoughts controul)
Did I for this expoe upon the Stage
My Roman Mother, not regarding Age,
Or Sex, (I call her Mother now, and o
I could the Abasinian Patriarch too,
To erve my Turn)? Did I for this, I ay,
Expoe Her naked as the Sunhine day;
And by the Crimes I faten'd on one Priet,
Inculcate boldly what were all the Ret?
Did I not paint'em wore, in all their cloe Debauhes,
Than the lew'd Priets of Iis, or the Gelt Reproaches
Of Phrygian Rites to Phrygian Goddes due?
Let the incredulous read my Play; 'tis new.
Under the Colour of Confeion, ee,
See how my Fryar pimps for Golden Fee;
See how I laid my Plot to bring him to't;
And made the Knave forwear himelf to boot.
Nor whether true or fale did I e're mind,
Reolving to my Mother to be kind.
Say, was not this good Service to my Church,
But after all to leave me in the Lurch,
As if I'had laid Defilement in her Porch!
(Thus raving, the embitter'd Bayes went on,)
Could a more vile Ingratitude be hown?
I will not bate thy Crime, Laomedon,
Unthankful to the Gods: for if the Gods
Were mercenary, where's the Pagan odds
Twixt Me and Them? Theirs was corporeal Pain,
Mine the more noble Labour of the Brain.
I was their Neptune; I their great Apollo,
Repair'd their Trojan Walls, when crack'd & hollow.
To me were thee Laomedons unjut,
So kind to toyl and labour upon Trut.
But now I'le pout whole Seas upon the Main,
And with a Deluge bring down all again.
And all their dear Heione's deflower;
At leat I'le trive what lies within my power,
And ue all Charms that in myterious Fury lurk.
This aid, the proud Revolter fell to work;
And a whole Winter and a Spring betow'd
The Burthen of his Cranium to unload.
Now Heaven forbid that we hould e're aail
Real Converion; Man is prone to fail:

l.hi: For Thoughtles Youth, oft wing'd with vain Deires,
And Manhood too, miled by wandring Fires,
Follow fale Lights; and when their Glimps is gon,
His Pride trikes out new Sparkles of his own.

lg.l: Howe're by happy chance when thoughtles Youth,
Has once decry'd the Sacred Paths of Truth,
And wandring Manhood has regain'd the Way
Whence thoe fale Meteors led him once atray,
The Path is free, when Concience atisfy'd,
To tread the Tracks of its unerring Guide,
'Tis Concience only, Concience can convince,
Concience unpotted and without pretence:
What Concience then calls bad before, is bad
To him whom uch a Concience does perwade,
And whither he directs, mut be obey'd.
But when with Charms Circean woo'd, he yields
To what Preferment and Ambition guilds;
When diappointed Hopes, and conequent Revenge
Puh on the Malecontent to frequent Change,
There, Concience, tript of her Celetial part;
Proves a Dieae, the Paion of the Heart:
A Phreny of the Mind, as when the Maid
Runs mad, to find her Virgin Love betray'd.
The Helm of Fools, that erves in merry Gales,
But in the ruder Storms and udden trokes,
Of boyt'rouly contending Paions, fails,
And throws unrudder'd Man upon the Rocks.
He then who with a rambling Concience moves
From his firt Choice, a wild Cimmerian roves,
And only changes Seats for better Pature.
If one Religion will not feed him, he's the Mater
Of his own Reaon, and another hall;
Indifferent which way the Cane may fall,
Or toward Italy, or the Levant.
He'l Mecca's Plenty change for Roman Want,
Still ready for the Turn; for all along
He's always in the right, but when he's wrong.
But let him ramble on; uch roaming Tartars
No Converts are, but poitive Deerters:
Chang'd in Opinion, not in Principles;
Religion's Vagabonds, and Gypie-Scrowlers;
To all Opinions protituted Tools,
And Pilgrims to the Shrines of Crowns and Dollers.
A ort of Craven Cocks that always Crow
On their own Dunghils, guarded from the blow
Of free Reply, their mainly dreaded Foe;
And ne're their Teeth, but till in afety, how.
With her pat Errors, hides her Head,
Only Contrition waits Her, mur'd within,
While he compleats the days of mourning for her Sin.
But here's a Ramping Infant Proelyte,
No ooner turn'd, but he hath Teeth to bite,
And ets up Champion e're half taught to fight.
Such certain Marks of tainted Concience,
He ne're can vail his cloven Innocence,
With all his Ulyean Eloquence.
Had he thus wrote when rudely he bemeard
His pury Fryar; or for a curt Reward,
Cat an officious Grin in Cromwel's Face,
His daring Vere had won him generous praie.
But when his Mother flourih'd, to write Pro,
And Con againt her, when he thought her low,
Shews him a meer Probationer, on Tryal,
Either for kind Reception, or denial.
For he has till with cunning Men to do,
Men that have reaon to upect it too,
That who has twice been fale, can n're prove true.
The Sinner therefore mut himelf out-rime,
And toil his bet for Expiation of his Crime;
Public Atonement, publick Expiation,
As well as private Sobs, and Whipcord Recreation,
Mut purge his Sins, & cure his rotten Reputation.
Commanded thus, an Altar up he rears,
Poetic Fires, and harpen'd Knives prepares,
Renews the Ancient Laws of Sacrifice,
And for the Slaughter Victims new Supplies.
Hares, Foxes, Apes, ne're offer'd yet before,
To thee the Panther add, the Wolf and Boar;
The Sacrificing Age had ne're uch tore.
A wond'rous Holocaut, and uch as might befit
The burning Rage of uch an Aetna Wit:
And the more meritorious, ince the Bigot
Would not exempt her Mother from the Fagot.
All this to Molach's Int'ret he deign'd:
For by his Medley Offerings now we find,
Which was the Idol of his ravenous Mind.
But hame on all ill Luck, th'Oblation came too late;
Indulgence, far more potent than his Hate,
Indulgence topp'd the hideous Blaze: For why?
The harmles Beats were fated not to die.
And all his murdering Characters, the Cream
Of his Stage-Wit, prov'd but the Forger's hame.
A Winter's Toil in Rapture o ill pent,
As made that Scandal, which for Harm was meant.
For when Revenge and Malice pout forth Rime,
'Tis all but Libel, never o ublime.
Poor ill-tim'd Poem! thou might't pity find,
Had't thou not uch a Maacre deign'd;
Had't thou not toil'd for general ditat,
And 'tead of large applaue, to be by all digrac't.
Uurping Bards, o boldly to apire,
To Sacred foreight and Prophetick Fire,
And Ours the mot unhappy of the Quire.
For had he had but half the Delphic Art
Of Bacon's Head, he might have par'd a Quart
Of Groyneland Oyl at leat, conum'd in Cotten,
To form a Brat, no ooner Born but Rotten.
And let it rot, a Babe of vile Digrace,
The Sire's Reproach, and hame of all the Race,
From a wore Fate, perhaps thereby redeem'd,
When the â€¢ oul Father of the Cub contemn'd
By all he has with o much Spite condemn'd,
And by his own detected, hall be forc'd
To hide a Head by both his Mothers Curs'd.
Bearing their Proverb in his Pia Mater,
They love the Treacherie that hate the Traytour

div.p:
Thus much in reference to the Authors deign in general. For as for his particular diputes which are o involv'd in Characters, and muffl'd up in Notion and Poetical Darknes; 'tis intended that Himelf, as bet undertanding his own meaning, hall modetly and civilly be his own Interpreter and Anwer himelf. Only by the way, before we bring D. againt D. to the Stake, I would fain know how Mr. Bays, that o well undertood the Nature of Beats, came to pitch upon the Hind and the Panther, to ign ifie the Church of Rome and the Church of England. Doubtles his Reply will be, becaue the Hind is a Creature harmles and Innocent: the Panther michievous and inexocrable. Let all this be granted; what is this to the Authors aburdity in the choice of his Beats? For the Scene of the Perecution is Europe, a part of the World which never bred Panthers ince the Creation of the Univere. On the other ide, grant his alluion paable, and then he tigmatizes the Church of England to be the mot Cruel, and mot voracious Creature that Ranges all the Lybean Deerts. A Character which hews him to have a trange mit before his Eyes when he reads Eccleiatical Hitory. And then aies he,
The Panther, ure the Noblet next the Hind,
And fairet Creature of the potted Kind.
Which is another Blunder; cujus Coutrarium verum et, For if Beauty, Strength and Courage advance the value of the everal parts of the Creation, without Quetion the Panther is far to be preferred before the Hind, a poor illy timorous ill-hap'd, bobtail'd Creature, of which a Score will hardly purchae the Skin of a true Panther. Had he lookd a little farther, Ludolphus would have furnih'd him with a Zecora, the mot beautiful of all the Four-footed Creatures in the World, to have L. 1. c 10. Hit. Aethiop. Cop'd with his Panther for Spots, and with his Hind for gentlenes and mildnes: of which one was Sold ingly to the Turkih Governor of Suaquena for two thouand Venetian Ducats. There had been a Beat for him, as pat as a Pudding for a Fryers Mouth. But to couple the Hind and the Panther, was jut like Sic parvis componere. And therefore he had better have put his Hind in a good Paty, or reerv'd her for ome more proper Alluion; for this, tho' his nimble beat have four Feet, will by no means run quatuor pedibus, tho' he had a whole Kennel of Hounds at her Heels.

But this was the Church of Englands Misfortune: rather than a true Poet will looe his Conceit, he'l bepatter the bet friends he has. For you mut know the Church of England was made a Panther for two Reaons. Firt at the eaily granted requet of a Thought, which was this,
Oh! could her inborn Stains be wah'd away,
She were too good to be a Beat of Prey.
Dii te Damaippe decaeq.â€”Donent Tonore, for thee mall Remainders of Pity.

The next was to hew ye that he could tame a Panther, while you ee the Hind and the Panther o lovingly dicouring together. A miracle ile aure ye equal if not uperior to the choicet in all
Ribadenira, if you conider how difficult a thing it is to dometicate that wild Animal.

In hort the whole Poem, if it may deerve that Name, is a piece of Deformed arrogant Nonence, and elf-contradiction, dret up in fine Language, like an ugly Brazen fac'd Whore peeping through the Cotly Trappings of a Point de Venie Cornet. I call it Nonence, becaue uneaonable; and Arrogant, becaue Impertinent; For could Mr. Bayes have o little Wit, to think himelf a ufficient Champion to decide the High Myteries of Faith and Tranubtantiation, and the nice diputes concerning Traditions and infallibility in a Dicoure between the Hind and the Panther, which undetermin'd hitherto, have exerci'd all the Learning in the World. Or could he think the Grand Arcana of Divinity a Subject fit to be handled in flourihing Rhime by the Author of the Duke of Guie, or the Conquet of Peru, or the Spanih Fryar: Doubts which Mr. Bayes is no more able to unfold, then Saffold to reolve a Quetion in Atrology. And all this only as a Tale to uher in his beloved Character, and to hew the excellency of his Wit in abuing Honet Men. If thee were his thoughts, as we cannot rationally otherwie believe, eeing that no man of undertanding will undertake an enterprie wherein he does not think himelf to have ome advantage of his Predeceors; then does this Romance, I ay, of the Panther and the Hind fall under the mot fatal Cenure of unreaonable folly and awcy Impertinence. Nor can I think that the more Solid, Prudent and Learned Perons of the Roman Church Con him any Thanks for laying the Prophane Fingers of a Turn-Coat upon the Altar of their Sacred Debates.

And o much for the Hind and Panther. Now you hall hear Mr. D. diputing againt Mr D. Mr. D. the Romanit againt Mr. D. the Protetant. As if he thought the controverted Points of Religion between differing Judgments were only Paradoxes for acute Ingenuities to play with, and hew the Dexterity of Wit to manage the Caue of Plaintiff or Defendant.

Mr. D. the Romanit dicouring of Traditions thus begins,
Hind and Panther, p. 41.
â€”But the Rule you lay
Has lead whole Flocks, and leads them till atray;
For did not Arrius firt, Socinus now
The Sons Eternal Glory diavow?
And did not they by Gopel Texts alone,
Condemn our Doctrine and maintain their own?
Have not all Heretic's the ame pretence,
To plead the Scriptures in their own defence?
How did the Nicene Council then decide
That trong debate, was it by Scripture try'd
Page 42.
No ure, to thoe the Rebel would not yield,
Squadrons of Texts he Marhall'd in the Field:
The good old Bihops took a impler way;
Each ask'd but what he heard his Father ay,
Or how he was intructed in his Youth,
And by Traditions Force upheld the Truth.

To this after he has put a frivolous Anwer of his own into the Panthers Mouth, he goes on;
I ee Tradition then is diallow'd,
When not evinc'd by Scripture to be true,
And Scripture, as interpreted by you:
But here you tread upon unfaithful Ground,
Unles you could infallibly expound
p. 44.
Which you reject as odious Poperie,
And throw the Doctrine back with corn on me;
Thus when you ay Traditions mut be try'd,
By Sacred Writ, whoe Sene your elves decide;
You aid no more, but that your elves mut be
The Judges of the Scripture Sene not we.
If not by Scripture, how can we be ure
Reply'd the Panther, what Tradition's ure?
For you may A proper Expreion, to put into the Mouth of the Church of England; as if he were a common Gamter. Palm upon us now for old,
All as they ay that Glitter is not Gold.
How, but by following her, reply'd the Dame,
To whom deriv'd from Sire to Son they came;
Where every Age does one another move,
And truts no farther than the next above,
Where all the Rounds like Jacob's Ladder rie,
The lowet in the Earth, the Top-mot in the Skies.
46. You mut evince Traditions to be forg'd:
Produce plain Proofs: Unblemih'd Authors ue,
As antient as thoe Authors they accue
Till when, 'tis not ufficient to defame,
And old poeion tands, till Elder quits the claim.

This was the Opinion of Mr. D. the Romanit upon the Cae of Traditions: now you hall hear the Judgment of Mr. D. the Protetant upon the ame Subject.
Relig. Lai. p. 20.
We hold and ay, we prove from Scripture plain,
That Chrit is God; the bold Socinian:
From the ame Scripture urges he's but Man.
Now what appeal can end th' impatient uite?
Both parts talk loudly, but the Rule is mute?
Shall I peak plain, and in a Nation Free,
Aume an honet Laymans Libertie.
I think according to my little skill,
To my own Meaning the Church of England. Mother Church ubmitting till,
That many have been av'd, and many may
That never heard the Quetion brought in play.
For the Streight Gate would be made treighter yet,
Were none admitted there but Men of Wit.
The Few by Nature form'd, with learning fraught,
Born to intruct, as others to be taught,
Mut tuddy well the acred Page, and ee
Which Doctrine, this or that, does bet agree
With the whole Tenour of the work Divine
And plainliet points to Heavens reveal'd deign.
Which Expoition flows from genuine ene,
And which is forc'd by Wit and Eloquence,
And then Traditions parts are ueful here
When general, old, diinteret and clear.
That antient Fathers thus expound the Page.
Give Truth, the Reverend Majety of Age;
For till, the nearer to the Spring we go
More limpid, more unoil'd the Waters flow.
Thus firt Traditions were a Proof alone,
Could we be certain uch they were, o known,
But ince ome flaws in long decent may be,
They make not truth, but probability.
Tradition written, therefore more Commends
Authority than what from Voice decends:
And this as perfect as its kind may be,
Rowls down to us the acred Hitorie.
Which from the Univeral Church receiv'd,
Is try'd, and afterward believ'd.

q.l: If Scripture, tho deriv'd from Heavenly Birth
Has been but carelely preerv'd on Earth.
If Gods own peopleâ€”
â€”Who did neither time nor tuddy pare.
To keep this Book untainted, unperplex'd
Let in gros Errors to Corrupt the Text.
Omitted Paragraphs, embroil'd the ene,
With vain Traditions topt the gaping Fence,
Which every common hand pull'd up with eae,
What aety from uch Bruhwood helps as thee
If Written Words from time are not ecur'd,
How can we think; have, Orall ounds endur'd.
Which thus tranmitted, if one Mouth has fail'd,
Immortal lies on Age are entail'd;
And that ome uch have been is prov'd too plin,

If we conider Meaning the Roman Intret, Church, and Profit.
Interet, Church and Gain.

div.p:
In the Second place Mr. D. the Romanit is for proving the Infallibility of his New Mother, which he thus Eaies to accomplih.
Hind and Panth. p 52.
And w â€¢ at one Saint has aid of Holy Paul,
He darkly Writ is true apply'd to all.
For this obcurity could Heaven provide,
More prudently than by a living Guide,
As doubts aroe the difference to decide?
The Hind begs the Quetion. A Guide was therefore needful, therefore made,
And if appointed, ure to be obeyd.
Thus with due Rev'rence, to th' Apotles Writ
By which my Sons are taught, to which ubmit:
I think thoe truths their acred works conrain,
The Church alone can certainly explain,
That following Ages leaning on the Pat,
May ret upon the primitive at lat,
Nor wou'd I thence the word no Rule inferr,
But none without the Church Interpreter. P 59.
Then granting that unerring Guide we want,
That uch there is, you tand oblig'd to grant,
Our Saviour ele were wanting to upply
Our needs, and obviate that neceity.
It then remains that Church can only be
The Guide which owns unfailing certainty. p. 60.
All which the His new Mother. Mother Church aerts her own
And with unrivall'd claim acends the Thrown.

[Exit. Hind. Now Enter Panther in the Peron of D. the Protetant
Relig. Laic. p. 18.
Such an Omnicient Church we wih indeed
'Twere worth both Tetaments, and cat in the Creed,
But if this Mother be a Guide o ure,
As can all Doubts reolve, all Truth ecure,
Then her Infallibility, as well
Where Copies are corrupt or lame, can tell;
Retore lot Canon with as little Pains,
And truly explicate what till remains.
Which yet no Councils dare pretend to do,
Unles, like Edras, they could write a new;
Strange Confidence till to interpret true,
Yet not be ure, That all they have explain'd
Is in the blet Original contain'd.
More afe, and much more modet 'tis to ay
God would not leave mankind without a Way.
And that the Scriptures, tho not every where
Free from corruption, or entire and clear,
Are uncorrupt, ufficient, clear, and entire
In all things which our needful Faith require;
If others in the fame Glas better ee
'Tis for themelves they look, but not for me;
For my Salvation mut its doom receive,
Not from what Others, but what I believe.

And p. 16. peaking in commendation of the Tranlation of Father Simon, he has thee words:
Where we may ee what Errors have been made,
Both in the Copier's, and Tranlator's Trade;
How Jewih, Popih Interets have prevail'd,
And where Infallibility has fail'd.

q.l: In thoe dark times they learn'd the Knack o well,
That by long ue they grew Infallible;
At lat, a knowing Age began t' enquire
If they the Book, or That did them inpire?
And making narrower earch they found, tho late,
That what they thought the Priets, was their Etate;
Taught by the Will produc'd, the Written Word,
How long they had been cheated on Record.
The Partial Papits would infer from hence,
Their Church, in lat reort, hould judg the ence;
But firt they would aume, with wondrous Art,
Themelves to be the whole, who are but part
Of that vat Frame, the Churchâ€”â€”

div.p:
And in his Preface to his Relig. Laic. he has this Expreion upon the ame Subject.
But by aerting the Scripture to be the Canon of our Faith, I have unavoidably created to my elf two ort of Enemies: The Papits indeed more directly, becaue they have kept the Scripture from us what they could, and have reerv'd to themelves a right of Interpreting what they have deliver'd, under pretence of Infallibility.

After this Mr. D. the Romanit falls into a Rapture, and extolls his new Mother to that degree, as if he were triving to outdo the Canticles. Saies he,
Hind and Panther, p. 61.
Behold! what marks of Majety he brings,
Richer than Ancient Heirs of Eatern Kings;
Her right hand holds the Scepter and the Keys
To hew whom he commands, and who obeys,
With thee to bind, or et the inner free,
With that t' aert piritual Royalty.
One in her elf, not rent by Schim, but ound,
Entire, one olid hining Diamond,
One central Principle of Unity
As undivided, o from Errors free,
As one in Faith, o one in Sanctity.
Thus one, thus pure, behold her largely pread.
Like the fair Ocean, from her Mother-Bed.
From Eat to Wet triumphantly he rides,
All Shores are water'd by her wealthy Tides.
The Gopel's ound diffus'd from Pole to Pole,
Where Winds can carry, and where Waves can roll,
The elf ame Doctrine of the Sacred Page,
Conveigh'd to every Clime, in every Age

But Mr. D the Protetant talks at another rate, as for Example,
Relig. Laic. p. 23.
In Times o'regrown with Rut and Ignorance,
A Gainful Trade their Clergy did advance,
When want of Learning kept the Lay-men low,
And none but Priets were authoriz'd to know.
When what mall Knowledg was, in them did dwell,
And he a God, who could but Read or Spell;
Then Mother Church did mightily prevail,
She parcell'd out the Bible by Retail;
But till expounded what he old or gave,
To keep it in her power to damn or ave:
Scripture was carce, and as the Market went,
Poor Lay-men took Salvation on Content.
As needy men take Money, good or bad,
Gods Word they had not, but the Priets they had;
Yet whate're fale Conveyances they made,
The Lawyer till was certain to be paid.

When he comes to the Panegyrick upon his preent Majety, where he had o tranending a Subject, and ought, tho it had been by way of Digreion, to have expended the whole Treaure of his Genius, Heaven's! what a difference there is between the feminine Encomiums of Mr. D. the Romanit, upon His preent Majety, and the ranting Raptures of Mr. D. the Independent upon a Monter of a Tyrant, as if the very Noie of Olivers ilver Prize had inpir'd him.

The choicet of Mr. D. the Romanit's thoughts, which he had to betow upon his Soveraign, are only thee.
A plain good man, whoe name is undertood
(So few deerve the Name of Plain and Good)
Of three fair Lineal Lordhips tood poes'd,
And livd, as reaon was, upon the Bet,
Inur'd to Hardhips from his early Youth;
Much had he done, and uffer'd for his Truth:
â€¢ t Land and Sea in many a doubtful fight,
Was never known a more Advent'rous Knight,
Who oftner drew his Sword, and always for the Right

But this is nothing to the lofty train, wherein Mr. D. the Independent Courts the fortune of a properous Rebel, in his Poem upon the Death of Oliver Cromwell, where he has thee towring Expreions.
His Grandeur he deriv'd from Heav'n alone,
For he was great e're Fortune made him o:
And Wars, like Mits that rie againt the Sun,
Made him but greater eem, not greater grow.
And yet Dominion was not his Deign,
We owe that Bleing not to him, but Heav'n,
Which to fair Acts unought Rewards did joyn,
Rewards that les to us than him were giv'n.
Swift and reitles through the Land be pat,
Like that bold Greek that did the Eat ubdue,
And made to Battels uch Heroic hat,
As if on Wings of Victory he flew.
He fought ecure of Fortune as of Fame,
Till by new Maps, the Iland might be hown,
Of Conquets which he trew'd where ere he came;
Thick as the Galaxie with Stars is own.

Nay the Tyrants Noe, that was the Laughter and Contempt of that time, could not cape the Adoration of his Independent Mue.
'Tis true his Count'nance did imprint an awe,
And nat'rally all Souls to his did bow,
As Wands of Divination downward draw,
And point to Beds where overaign Gold doth grow.

By the way, take notice what a Yerk he gives his Mother the Church of Rome in the ame Panegyrick, for then it was convenient o to do.
That Old unquetion'd Pyrate of the Land,
Proud Rome, with dread the Fate of Dunkirk hear'd;
And trembling, wih'd behind more Alps to tand,
Altho an Alexander were her Guard.
By all which the Reader may perceive how much the Enthuiam of thoe days urmounted the flagging Wit of thee times.

But now you will find Mr. D. the Romanit, and Mr. D. the Protetant at Dagger's drawing about the Plot, and the Papits too, which is more; o poitively oppoite one to the other, as if he had two Seats of Judgment, the one in his forehead, and the other in the Nape of his Neck.

Mr. D. the Romanit upbraids the Church-men of England, and gives her good Intructions in thee Lines.
Hind and Panther. p. 112.
To name the Tet, would put you in a Rage,
You charge not that on any former Age:
But mile to think how Innocent you tand,
Arm'd by a weapon put into your hand;
Yet till remember that you weild a Sword
Forg'd by your Foes againt your ov'raign Lord,
Deign'd to hew th' Imperial Cedar down,
Defraud Succeion, and disheir the Crown.

p.hi: And thence tranporting himelf to the Plot.

q.l: What more could you have done than now you do,
Had Oates and Bedlow, and their Plot been true?
Some pecious Reaons for thoe wrongs were found,
The Dire Magicians threw their Mits around,
And wiemen walk'd as on inchanted Ground:
But now when Time has made th' Impoture plain,
What new Deluion charms your cheated Eyes again?
The painted Harlot might a while bewitch,
But why the Hagg uncas'd, and all obcene with itch?

div.p:
Had Mr. D. the Romanist but whiper'd thee words at Will's Coffee-houe, time was when, Mr. D. the Protetant had certainly inform'd againt him, and procur'd him corporal Punihment: For, do but hear Mr. D. the Protetants Opinion at that time in teady Proe, in his Protetant Epitle to Religio Laici.
A General and uninterrupted Plot of their Clergy (meaning the Papits) ever ince the Reformation, I uppoe all Protetants believe. For 'tis not reaonable to believe but that o many of their Orders, as were outed from their Fat Poeions, wou'd endeavour a Re-entrance againt thoe whom they account Hereticks. As for the late deign, Mr. Coleman's Letters, for ought I know, are the bet evidence; and what they dicover without Wire-drawing their Sence, or malicious Gloes, all Men of Reaon conclude Credible. If there be any more than this required of me, I mut believe it as well as I am able in pite of the Witnees, and out of a decent Conformity to the Votes of Parliament. For I uppoe the Fanaticks will not
allow the private Spirit in this Cae. Here the Infallibillity is in one part of the Goverment, and our Undertanding as well as our Wills are repreented.
But to return to the Roman Catholicks. How can we be ecure from the Practice of the Jeuited Papits in that Religion? For not two or three of that Order, as ome would impoe upon us; but almot the whole Body of them are of Opinion that their Infallible Mater has a Right over Kings, not only in pirituals, but in temporals. Not to Name Mariana, Bellarmin, Emanuel Sa, Molina, Santarel, Simancha, and at leat twenty others of forreign Countries, we can produce of our own Nation, Campian, and Doleman, or Parons; beides, many are nam'd whom I have not read, who all of them attet, That the Pope can give away the Right of any Soveraign Prince, if he hall warp never o little; but if he once comes to be excommunicated, then the Bond of Obedience is taken off from his Subjects, and they may and ought to drive him like another Nebuchaduezzar from exerciing Dominion over Chritians: And to this they are bound by Virtue of Divine Precept, and by all the ties of Concience, under no les Penalty than Damnation. And their Champion Bellarmin has told the World, that the King of England is a Vaal to the Pope, and that he holds in Villenage of his Roman Landlord.

Here is Contradiction upon Contradiction. A Plot believ'd, and a Plot denied: Loyal Roman Catholick Subjects, that hold it Lawful to depoe thoe Soveraigns, are branded with his mark of Wicklifs Brood, innate Antipathy to Kings.
Hind. and P. p. 11. Which makes me wonder that Mr. D. the Protetant, did not call in all his Heretical Writings, and burn 'em by the hand of the Common Hangman, before he revolted to write his Hind and Panther.

Now, by the way of Corollary, a little more of your Chritian Patience gentle Reader, and hear his low Opinion of the Martyrs of the Roman Faith, as he owns it in his Religio Laici, p. 13. where undertaking to prove,
That if the Gentiles whom no Law inpir'd
By nature did what was by Law requir'd.
They might be ay'd, He goes on thus.
Mot righteous Doom; becaue a Rule reveal'd
Is none to thoe from whom it was conceal'd.
Then thoe who follow'd Reaons Dictates right,
Liv'd up, and lifted high their Natural Light,
With Socrates, may ee their Maker's Face,
While Thouand Rubrick Martyrs want a place.

Nor could ever Shimei be thought to have curs'd David more bitterly than he permits his Friend to Blapheme the Roman Priet-hood in his Epilogue to the Spanih Fryer; In which Play he himelf has acted his own Part like a true younger Son of Noah, as may be eaily een in the firt Edition of that Comedy, which would not pas Muter a econd time without Emendations and Corrections. And as for the Epilogue, affix'd by his allowance to the Play, which in effect is the ame thing, as if he had done it himelf; after the Author had tigmatiz'd the Roman Clergy for Perons that would pimp and perjure themelves, and conequently commit any other Villanies for Money, his Friend thus concludes.
There's none I'me ure who is a friend to love,
But will our Fryers Character approve.
The ablet park among you, ometimes needs
Such pious helps for Charitable Deeds.
Our Church, alas, as Rome objects, does want
The Ghotly Comforts for the falling Saint;
This gains them their Whore-converts, and may be
The reaon of the Growth of Popery.
So Mahomets Religion came in Fahion,
By the large leave it gave to Fornication.
Fear not the Guilt, if you can pay for't well;
There is no Dives in the Roman Hell.
Gold opens the treight Gate, and lets him in,
But want of Money is a mortal in;
How are men cozen'd till with hews of Good?
The Bawds bet Mask is the grave Fryers Hood.
'Tis a mock War between the Priet and Devil,
VVhen they think fit, they can be very civil.
They boat the Gift of Heaven is in their power,
Well may they give the God they can devour
Still to the ick and dead their Claims they lay,
For 'tis on Carrion that the Vermin prey.
Nor have they les Dominion on our Life;
They trot the Husband, and they pace Wife.
Rouze up you Cuckcolds of the Northern Climes,
And learn from Sweden to prevent uch Crimes;
Unman the Fryer, and leave the Holy Drone,
To hum in his foraken Hive alone:
He'l work no Honey, when his ting is gone.
Your Wives and Daughters oon will leave the Cells,
When they have lot the ound of Aaron's Bells.

Now that you may ee his Friend and he were both agreed, you hall find the Author himelf concluding his econd Act of his Spanih Fryer to the ame tune, where he brings in the tempted Elvira, commending the Fryer for managing his buines o well in thee words.
Elv.
This Fryer is a comfortable Man, he will know nothing of the buines, but does it all:
Pray Wives and Virgins at your time of need,
For a true Guide, of my good Fathers breed.

And in the very firt Scene of the third Act, the ame Lady cries out,
Well, if I prove frail,â€”never Woman had uch an Husband
to provoke her, uch a Lover to allure her, or uch a Confeor to abolve her.

And a little farther, ays Gomez, the jealous Husband,
â€”When a winging Sin is to be committed, nothing will cover it o cloe as a Fryers Hood, for there the Devil plays at Bo-peep; puts out his Horns to do micheif, and then hrinks 'em back for afety, like a Snale into her hell.
The ence of the Epilogue all along: And enough to hew how oon a Gentleman may alter his Opinion in point of Religion.
